bibl.title: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to Kenneth F. Maxcy, August 30, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] discusses past experiments and problems with the use of the blood index in relation to malaria.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to Kenneth F. Maxcy, August 30, 1923
div1.opener:
Miscl
Maxcy
/LC
Badin Hospital,
Badin, N. C.,
August 30, 1923.
Dr. Kenneth Maxcy,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Care State Health Officer,
Montgomery, Alabama.
Dear Doctor Maxcy:
div1.p:
About the problem in relation to the blood index of malaria
about which you asked, I had purposed to wait until I got back home,
where I have access to notes etc., but as I am still in bed I will out-
line it to you as well as I can without notes and send you a supple-
mentary letter when I get to Washington, which I think will be shortly.
The problem was

1/ To determine what proportion of infections would be
missed by a blood examination (thick film) by a carefully trained man on
a single examination.

2/ What proportion of cases found positive by such examination
in the late fall would be found negative (presumably, but not neces-
sarily, cured spontaneously) in the spring or summer under the originalordinary
conditions of life in the country on plantations in the South. The or-
dinary conditions of life do not imply the exclusion of quinine or its
efficient use--simply the people living as they habitually live during the
fall: winter and spring.
Let me take the second problem first:

The desireability of its solution--or rather of the in-
verse problem: the proportion of relapses (parasitic or symptomatic) is
stressed by Ross in his
“Prevention of Malaria.”
Malaria.”

A good deal of work on it has been done by the Italians--especially by
Cacina and by Sella. Ross himself gives data on this problem and Bass has
a note on it in his work on the Yazoo, where, however--judging partly by
the statistics of Taylor in Arkansas and my can observations at Wilson--
his proportion of relapses is too high. My recollection is that he found
from a little over 50% to about 69% relapses among the people who had mal-
aria in 1918: but you have access to his papers.

This problem was taken up in 1914, It was planned to take a care-
ful blood index of a badly infected community after the date at which in-
fection could be contracted, taking the names of all persons. To take
the same index by the same man--or one equally careful and skillful--in
the early spring before malaria could be contracted. A comparison of these
would give us data upon the subject--for instance: if 20% of all those that
were positive in the fall showed negative in the spring and continued to
show negative until well into the malaria season, it would be evidence--
although not quite proof--that that proportion, under the conditions that
existed, had freed themselves from infection. I say not quite proof, be-
cause for proof these people should be conveyed to some place where they
were not exposed to infection at all and watched a long time. On the other
hand, if 20% of those found negative in the fall were found positive in the
early spring before it was reasonably possible to contract malaria it would
be proof not merely evidence) that 20% at least of infections had been miss-
ed on our supposedly careful examination. I say'at least'because it is ob-
vious that if a careful examination in the late fall missed finding some
infections a similar careful examination in the early spring might do the
same and 20% would not represent all the infections that existed. This
difficulty could be met, however, by keeping our men who were negative
in the fall out of contact with infected Anopheles for a considerable time
until we could be certain that no parasites could be found in their blood.

In the spring (reasonable chances of exposure to infected Anopheles)

we must take into consideration the hibernated females which--in any district
we have in the United States--are indeed uninfected, but which if they en-
ter houses (as quads do) can readily become infected from carriers in whom,
of course, the parasite does winter and, it being warm in the house, at the
and of 20 or 30 days infect others.

This matter has never been worked out in America and frankly I am in-
clined to think that a considerable number of the early spring cases are
by infections by these hibernated females becoming thus infected in houses
and staying in houses or maybe warm stables long enough to become infective.
This, of course, could happen before the flight of the earliest spring brood
who have no houses to warm up in.

Angus McDonald has laid some stress on this in the early spring post
bellum malaria in England.

Dr. von Ezdorf took a blood index (thick film) at Scott, Miss. in
the fall of 1914. At my instance, Mayne took a similar index there in Febru-
ary 1915 in conjunction with his great work on the hibernation of the parasite
in the mosquito. As I remember the figures------my memory is quite relia-
ble, but I will send the exact data when I get home--von Ezdorf out of
either 1640 or 1460 people found a positive blood index of 49 8/10%.
Mayne on 1160 specimens found an index of 41.1 or 41.2. Both were careful
men: both sused the same method in getting the specimens and in examining
them: both took a sufficient number of specimens to eliminate accidental er-
rors of observation: both found approximately the same number of positives.
If then there was no chance of new infections in the interval between these
indices one must take one horn or the other of this dilema:

(a) either the men that were positive in the fall were positive in
the spring and those that were negative in the fall were negative in the
spring or

(b) that equal number changed from negative to positive and from
positive to negative.
negative.

In only a small number--103 is my recollection--were specimens taken
from the same men whose names were recorded by von Ezdorf as positive and
he kept no record of his negative cases. Of these 103 (?) 53, as I re-
collect were now negative (nearly 52%). Now 103 is not enough to make a
percentage on, but if this proportion held true of other positives turning
to negatives we will have to accept (b) as our explanation as a result of
these observations.

Mayne's observation was certainly made before the spring flight of
Anopheles: his own dissections of wild Anopheles stisfy me that it was made
before the hibernated ones became infective. I am not, however, so certain
that von Ezdorf's index was taken after all reasonable probality of in-
fection was passed.

I made several attempts with Mayne at the rural units of the peni-
tentiaries of Louisiana and Mississippi to repeat this experiment record-
ing the names, and had dates which would be beyond dispute, yet the posi-
tive data was so small that while I have it it is not enough to draw con-
clusions from

I did send to the Central Office, however--in 1917 as I recollect --
a rather long-winded equation by which--admitting certain postulates, which
I confess are only approximately correct--one can, from a few satisfactory
observations of this kind, determine the proportion of infections that are miss-
ed at a careful examination by the method used and therefor the faction by
which this positive finding must be multiplied to get approximately a true
infection from such a blood index. It is rather an intricate equation,
but not especially so. Certainly not any more so than the one Ross gives
for the increase and diminution of malaria with the increase and diminution
of the number of Anopheles present, and, at any rate, it is not in the
same class with Pearl's transcendental equation definition of Ross', which
while I could follow I would never recommend to any friend as light reading.
